member.name: T:Eto.ColumnBinding
member.summary: Column/Index binding for objects implementing or
member.remarks: This binding is an indirect binding on a particular column/index of each object. This is used to get/set values of a passed-in object to the and .

member.name: T:Eto.IndirectBinding
member.summary: Provides an indirect binding to an indeterminate source/destination
member.remarks:
This binding does not directly bind to an object - you must pass the object to get/set the value. The differs in that it binds directly to an object.
The IndirectBinding is useful when you want to use the same binding on multiple objects, such as when binding cells in a .
Typically one would use or which are ways to retrieve either a property value or column/index-based value.

member.name: T:Eto.Binding
member.summary: Base class for binding between a value and another
member.remarks: This is the base of any type of binding. Some bindings may only be used to get/set a single value (e.g. ), whereas the can link two objects' values together

member.summary: Unbind this from the target object(s)
member.remarks: Typically a binding may handle an event for when the target object(s) property values are changed. This is called to unbind the binding from the objects so that they can be garbage collected

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.DashStyle.Dashes
member.summary: Gets the dashes and gaps for this style
member.remarks:
The values specified are the dash lengths and gap lengths in alternating order. The lengths are multiplied by the thickness of the pen.
For example, values of 2, 1 would have a dash of (2 * thickness) followed by a gap of (1 * thickness).
member.value: The dashes to use for a pen

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.DashStyle.Offset
member.summary: Gets the offset of the first dash
member.remarks: A value of 1 indicates that the first dash should start at the (1*thickness) of the pen.
member.value: The offset of the first dash, in multiples of pen thickness

member.name: T:Eto.InstanceWidget
member.summary: Widget that represents an instance of an object
member.remarks:
The InstanceWidget is used for controls and objects that represent an instance of an object.
Typically, most widgets will derive from this class. However, if you only have static methods of a class you will still need a handler implementation and the class provides that.
InstanceWidgets also wrap the ability to handle late-bound events on the backend control.

member.name: T:Eto.Widget
member.summary: Base widget class for all objects requiring a platform-specific implementation
member.remarks:
The Widget is the base of all abstracted objects that have platform-specific implementations.
The is the class that's typically used as a base as it provides an instance of the platform-specific object, as well as adds the ability to handle events on the object. This is used as the base for static objects such as the or .
To implement the handler for a widget, use the as the base class.

member.name: P:Eto.InstanceWidget.ControlObject
member.summary: Gets the instance of the platform-specific object
member.remarks:
This can sometimes be useful to get the platform-specific object. It is more preferred to use the and cast that to the platform-specific handler class which can give you additional methods and helpers to do common tasks.
For example, the object's handler for OS X has a AddFullScreenMenuItem property to specify if you want full screen support in your app.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Control.DataContext
member.summary: Gets or sets the data context for this widget for binding
member.remarks:
Subclasses may override the standard behaviour so that hierarchy of widgets can be taken into account.
For example, a Control may return the data context of a parent, if it is not set explicitly.

member.name: P:Eto.Forms.Grid.SelectedItem
member.summary: If there is exactly one selected item, returns it, otherwise returns null.

member.name: T:Eto.Forms.GridViewSelection
member.summary:
Manages the selection of a grid view, and maintains it under four types of operations:
1) The user changes the selection in the control. In this case the selection indexes are recalculated. 2) The application programmatically changes the selection using SelectRow(), SelectAll(), etc. In this case the internal selection is updated and SelectionChanged is fired. 3) A sort or filter is applied to the GridView. 4) The DataStore changes, i.e. items are added, removed or modified. (c) 2013 by Vivek Jhaveri See LICENSE for full terms

member.name: T:Eto.Forms.ThemedControlHandler`2
member.summary:
Base class for implementing Eto controls using other Eto controls. This allows a single implementation to be used in multiple platforms and is useful in a couple of scenarios:
a) Creating default implementations of a control on platforms that do not support the control natively.
b) Implementing a control with a non-native look and feel that is consistent across platforms. The Eto control used to create the custom implementation, e.g. Panel The control being implemented, eg TabControl

member.name: M:Eto.WidgetHandler`2.CreateControl
member.summary: Called to create the platform control for this widget
member.remarks:
This is used so that it is easy to override the control that is created for a handler. If you derive from an existing platform handler to override it's behaviour, you can change the class that is created via this method. You will still need that control to be of the same type that the original handler has defined, but you will be able to subclass the platform control to provide any specific functionality if needed.
This gets called automatically by , so you should only set properties on your control in the handler's overridden initialize method, after the base class' initialize has been called.
member.returns: A new instance of the platform-specific control this handler encapsulates

member.summary: Class to help implement change handling for a
member.remarks:
This is used for the platform handler of controls that use collections. This class helps detect changes to a collection so that the appropriate action can be taken to update the UI with the changes.
Use this class as a base when you are detecting changes for an . If the object also implements , it will get changed events. Otherwise, you must register a new collection each time.
member.typeparam: Type of items in the data store
Type of the data store to detect changes on

member.name: T:Eto.CollectionChangedHandler`2
member.summary: Class to help implement collection changed events on a data store
member.remarks:
This is used for the platform handler of controls that use collections. This class helps detect changes to a collection so that the appropriate action can be taken to update the UI with the changes.
This is a simple helper that is much easier to implement than handling the event directly.

member.name: M:Eto.CollectionChangedHandler`2.AddRange(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{`0})
member.summary: Adds multiple items to the end of the collection
member.remarks:
This simply calls for each item in the list. If there is a faster mechanism for doing so, implementors should override this method.
For example, sometimes adding a single item will update the UI for each item, this should be overridden so the UI is updated after all items have been added.
member.param: Enumeration of items to add to the end of the collection

For example, sometimes inserting a single item will update the UI for each item, this should be overridden so the UI is updated after all items have been inserted.
member.param: Index to start adding the items

member.name: M:Eto.CollectionChangedHandler`2.RemoveRange(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Removes a specified count of items from the collection starting at the specified index
member.remarks:
This simply calls for each item to remove. If there is a faster mechanism for doing so, implementors should override this method.

member.name: T:Eto.Generator
member.summary: Base generator class for each platform
member.remarks:
The generator takes care of creating the platform-specific implementations of each control. Typically, the types are automatically found from the platform assembly, however you can also create your own platform-specific controls by adding the types manually via
The types are found by the interface of the control. For example the control uses the interface for its platform implementation. The generator will automatically scan an assembly for a class that directly implements this interface for its platform implementation (if it hasn't been added manually).

member.name: P:Eto.Generator.ID
member.summary: Gets the ID of this generator
member.remarks: The generator ID can be used to determine which generator is currently in use. The generator does not necessarily correspond to the OS that it is running on, as for example the GTK platform can run on OS X and Windows.

member.name: P:Eto.Generator.Current
member.summary: Gets the current generator
member.remarks:
Typically you'd have only one platform generator active at a time, and this holds an instance to that value. The current generator is set automatically by the class when it is initially created.
This will be used when creating controls, unless explicitly passed through the constructor of the control. This allows you to use multiple generators at one time.

member.name: P:Eto.Generator.HasCurrent
member.summary: Returns true if the current generator has been set.

member.name: P:Eto.Generator.Detect
member.summary: Returns the current generator, or detects the generator to use if no current generator is set.
member.remarks:
This detects the platform to use based on the generator assemblies available and the current OS.
For windows, it will prefer WPF to Windows Forms. Mac OS X will prefer the Mac platform. Other unix-based platforms will prefer GTK.

member.name: P:Eto.Generator.ValidateGenerator
member.summary:
Can be used by apps that switch between generators.
Set this property at the start of a block of code. All objects created after that point are verified to use this generator.
If null, no validation is performed.

member.name: T:Eto.StyleWidgetHandler`1

member.remarks: This allows you to add additional logic or set properties on the widget based on the styles set on the widget.
member.typeparam: Type of widget to style
member.param: Widget instance that is being styled

member.name: T:Eto.StyleHandler`1
member.summary: Delegate to handle styling a widget handler
member.remarks: This allows you to add additional logic or set properties on the widget and platform-specific control(s) based on the styles set on the widget.
member.typeparam: Type of the handler to style
member.param: Handler instance that is being styled

member.name: T:Eto.StyleWidgetHandler
member.summary: Obsolete. Do not use.

member.name: T:Eto.StyleWidgetControlHandler`2
member.summary: Obsolete. Do not use.

member.name: T:Eto.Style
member.summary: Style manager for widgets
member.remarks:
Styles allow you to attach custom platform-specific logic to a widget. In your platform-specific assembly, use Style.Add<H>(string, StyleHandler<H>) to add the style logic with the same id.
Typically, your styles will be added in your platform-specific executable, before your application is run.

member.name: M:Eto.Style.Add(System.String,Eto.StyleWidgetHandler)
member.summary: Obsolete. Do not use

member.name: M:Eto.Style.Add``1(System.String,Eto.StyleWidgetHandler{``0})
member.summary: Adds a style for a widget
member.remarks:
Styling a widget allows you to access the widget, but not the platform-specific controls (in a type-safe way).
Typically, you'd use Style.Add<H>(string, StyleHandler<H>) instead, which will add a style based on the widget handler, which will give you direct and type safe access to platform-specifics of the widget.
member.typeparam: Type of the widget to style
member.param: Delegate with your logic to style the widget

member.name: M:Eto.Style.Add``2(System.String,Eto.StyleWidgetControlHandler{``0,``1})
member.summary: Obsolete. Do not use.

member.name: M:Eto.Style.AddHandler``1(System.String,Eto.StyleHandler{``0})
member.summary: Obsolete. Do not use.

member.name: M:Eto.Style.Add``1(System.String,Eto.StyleHandler{``0})
member.summary: Adds a style for a widget handler
member.remarks:
Styling a widget handler allows you to access both the widget and the platform-specifics for the widget.
To use this, you would have to add a reference to one of the Eto.Platform.*.dll's so that you can utilize the platform handler directly. Typically this would be called before your application is run.
member.typeparam: Type of the handler that should be styled
member.param: Delegate with your logic to style the widget and/or platform control

member.name: E:Eto.Style.StyleWidget
member.summary: Event to handle when a widget has being styled

Calculates the distance of the two colors in the RGB scale
This is useful for comparing two different color values to determine if they are similar.

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Color.TryParse(System.String,Eto.Drawing.Color@,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Converts the specified string to a color
member.remarks:
The string can be any of these formats: - #AARRGGBB or #RRGGBB (where ARGB are hex values) - 0xAARRGGBB or 0xRRGGBB - [named] (where [named] is a name of one of the properties in ) - [uint] (where [uint] is a base-10 ARGB value) - [red], [green], [blue] (where each component is a value from 0-255) - [alpha], [red], [green], [blue] (where each component is a value from 0-255)
If the string is null or empty, this will return
member.param: Color struct with the parsed value, or Transparent if value is invalid
Culture to use to parse the values
member.returns: True if the value was successfully parsed into a color, false otherwise

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Color.FromElementId(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new color from an Element ID value
member.remarks: This algorithm is from the SVG# code base: The counter is used to generate IDs in the range [0,2^24-1] The 24 bits of the counter are interpreted as follows: [red 7 bits | green 7 bits | blue 7 bits |shuffle term 3 bits] The shuffle term is used to define how the remaining high bit is set on each color. The colors are generated in the range [0,127] (7 bits) instead of [0,255]. Then the shuffle term is used to adjust them into the range [0,255]. This algorithm has the feature that consecutive ids generate visually distinct colors.
member.returns: A new instance of a Color with the value from the element id

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Color.ToElementId
member.summary: Converts this color to an Element ID value
member.returns: The element id value of this color

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Graphics.Flush
member.summary: Flushes the drawing (for some platforms)
member.remarks:
Flushing the drawing will force any undrawn changes to be shown to the user. Typically when you are doing a lot of drawing, you may want to flush the changed periodically so that the user does not think the UI is unresponsive.
Some platforms may not have the concept of flushing the graphics, so this would do nothing

member.name: T:Eto.Drawing.Icon
member.summary: Represents an icon which allows for multiple sizes of an image
member.remarks:
The formats supported vary by platform, however all platforms do support loadin windows .ico format.
Using an icon for things like menus, toolbars, etc are preferred so that each platform can use the appropriate sized image.
For HiDPI/Retina displays (e.g. on OS X), this will allow using a higher resolution image automatically.

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Palette.Save(System.IO.BinaryWriter,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Saves this palette to the specified binary writer in (A)RGB components
member.remarks: Each component is saved as a single byte (regardless of the value of ). It is saved in the order of Alpha (if is true), Red, Green, then Blue.
member.param: Writer to write the data to
Shift amount for each component. 0 = 0-255, 1 = 0-128, 2 = 0-64, etc
True to include alpha, false to only include RGB components

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Palette.Load(System.IO.BinaryReader,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Loads the palette from the specified binary reader in (A)RGB components
member.remarks: Each component is read as a single byte (regardless of the value of ). It is read in the order of Alpha (if is true), Red, Green, then Blue.
member.param: Reader to read the data from
Number of palette entried to load
Shift amount for each component. 0 = 0-255, 1 = 0-128, 2 = 0-64, etc
True to include the alpha component, false to only read RGB components

member.name: T:Eto.Drawing.BitmapData
member.summary: Bitmap data information when accessing a 's data directly
member.remarks:
The bitmap data is accessed through , which locks the data for direct access using the pointer.
Ensure you call with the same instance when you are done accessing or writing the data.

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.BitmapData.#ctor(Eto.Drawing.Image,System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Object)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the BitmapData class
member.param: Width of each scan row, in bytes
Platform specific object for the bitmap data (if any)

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.BitmapData.TranslateArgbToData(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Translates a 32-bit ARGB value to the platform specific pixel format value
member.remarks:
Use this method to translate an ARGB (Alpha in most significant) to the value required by the bitmap for the pixel.
Each platform can have a different pixel format, and this allows you to abstract setting the data directly.
The ARGB value can be easily retrieved using .
For non-alpha bitmaps, the alpha component will be ignored
member.param: ARGB pixel value to translate into the platform-specific format
member.returns: Platform-specific format of the pixels that can be set directly onto the data

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.BitmapData.TranslateDataToArgb(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Translates the platform specific pixel format to a 32-bit ARGB value
member.remarks:
Use this method to translate an value from the bitmap data to a 32-bit ARGB (Alpha in most significant byte).
Each platform can have a different pixel format, and this allows you to abstract getting the data into a 32-bit colour.
The ARGB value can be easily handled using .
For non-alpha bitmaps, the alpha component will be ignored
member.param: Platform specific bitmap data for a pixel to translate
member.returns: Translated ARGB value from the bitmap data

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.BitmapData.Dispose
member.summary: Releases all resource used by the object.
member.remarks: Call when you are finished using the . The method leaves the in an unusable state. After calling , you must release all references to the so the garbage collector can reclaim the memory that the was occupying.

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.BitmapData.Image
member.summary: Gets the image this data is for

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.BitmapData.BitsPerPixel
member.summary: Gets the bits per pixel

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.BitmapData.BytesPerPixel
member.summary: Gets the bytes per pixel

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.BitmapData.Data
member.summary: Gets the pointer to the data of the bitmap
member.remarks:
This does not include any headers, etc. so it directly points to the beginning of the data.
Each row may not be on a pixel boundary, so to increment to the next row, use the to increment the pointer to the next row.

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.BitmapData.Flipped
member.summary: Gets a value indicating that the data is flipped (upside down)
member.remarks:
Some platforms may handle memory bitmaps in a flipped fashion, such that the top of the image is at the bottom of the data.
If this is true, then the starting row of the data is the bottom row of the image.

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.BitmapData.ScanWidth
member.summary: Gets the width (in bytes) of each scan line (row) of pixel data
member.remarks: When advancing to the next row, use this to increment the pointer. The number of bytes for each row might not be equivalent to the bytes per pixel multiplied by the width of the image.

member.name: P:Eto.Drawing.BitmapData.ControlObject
member.summary: Gets the platform-specific control object for the bitmap data

member.name: T:Eto.Drawing.ColorHSB
member.summary: Color representation in HSB color model
member.remarks:
This allows you to manage a color in the HSB (otherwise known as HSV) cylindrical model.
This is a helper class to handle HSB colors. Whenever a color is used it must be converted to a struct first, either by using or the implicit conversion.

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.ColorHSB.Distance(Eto.Drawing.ColorHSB,Eto.Drawing.ColorHSB)
member.summary: Calculates the 'distance' of two HSB colors
member.remarks:
This is useful for comparing two different color values to determine if they are similar.
Typically though, gives the best result instead of this method.
member.returns: The overall distance/difference between the two colours. A lower value indicates a closer match

member.name: T:Eto.Drawing.ColorHSL
member.summary: Color representation in the HSL color model
member.remarks:
This allows you to manage a color in the HSL cylindrical model.
This is a helper class to handle HSL colors. Whenever a color is used it must be converted to a struct first, either by using or the implicit conversion.

member.name: F:Eto.Drawing.ColorHSL.Empty
member.summary: Obsolete. Do not use.

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.ColorHSL.Distance(Eto.Drawing.ColorHSL,Eto.Drawing.ColorHSL)
member.summary: Calculates the 'distance' of two HSL colors
member.remarks:
This is useful for comparing two different color values to determine if they are similar.
The HSL comparison algorithm, while not essentially accurate, gives a good representation of like-colours to the human eye. This method of calculating distance is preferred over the other methods (RGB, CMYK, HSB)
member.returns: The overall distance/difference between the two colours. A lower value indicates a closer match

member.name: T:Eto.EnumerableChangedHandler`2
member.summary: Class to help implement change handling on an
member.remarks:
This is used for the platform handler of controls that use collections. This class helps detect changes to a collection so that the appropriate action can be taken to update the UI with the changes.
Use this class as a base when you only have an . If the object also implements it will get changed events otherwise you must register a new collection each time.
member.typeparam: Type of each item in the enumerable
Type of collection

member.summary: Implements the mechanism for finding the index of an item (the slow way)
member.remarks: If the collection object implements , this will not get called as it will call it's method of getting the index. This is used as a fallback.

member.returns: Index of the item, or -1 if not found

member.name: T:Eto.DualBindingMode
member.summary: Mode of the
member.remarks: This specifies what direction the updates of each of the properties are automatically handled. Only properties that have a Changed event, or objects that implement will handle automatically updating the binding.

member.name: F:Eto.DualBindingMode.OneWay
member.summary: Binding will update the destination if the source property is changed

member.summary: Binding will update both the destination or source if updated on either the source or destination, respectively

member.name: F:Eto.DualBindingMode.OneWayToSource
member.summary: Binding will update the source if the destination property is changed

member.name: F:Eto.DualBindingMode.OneTime
member.summary: Binding will only set the destination from the source when initially bound
member.remarks: This is ideal when you want to set the values of the destination, then only update the source at certain times using the method.

member.name: T:Eto.Drawing.FontTypeface
member.summary: A font type that specifies the characteristics of a variation
member.remarks:
Each FontFamily can have different variations, such as Bold, Italic, Bold and Italic, etc.
This class represents each supported typeface of a particular font family, and can be used to create a instance that uses this typeface, using the constructor.

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.Brushes.ClearCache(Eto.Generator)

member.param: Generator to clear the brush cache for

member.name: T:Eto.IXmlReadable
member.summary: Interface to declare an object that can serialize to/from xml
member.remarks:
This interface is useful when you are reading/writing objects to xml manually by using .
There are methods to load/save a collection of child objects and singular child objects when you implement this interface which makes reading/writing to xml super easy.

member.name: T:Eto.CreateFromXml`1
member.summary: Delegate to create the specified object from an XmlElement
member.remarks:
This is used for certain to create child objects when reading xml elements.
The implementors of this delegate typically do not need to read the object from XML, just create the instance of the object based on certain criteria (e.g. a type or ID)
member.typeparam: Type of object to create based on the element
member.param: Element to create the object from
member.returns: A new instance of the specified type for the element

member.name: M:Eto.XmlExtensions.ReadChildXml``1(System.Xml.XmlElement,System.String)
member.summary: Reads a single child xml element from the specified element as a given type
member.remarks:
This is useful for reading a (singular) child element of an xml element into an object that implements .
If you want to use a class that requires certain parameters for construction or to create a different derived type based on certain attributes of the child xml element, use instead.
member.typeparam: Type of child to read (must be )

member.returns: A new instance of the specified type if the child element exists with properties read from xml, otherwise null

member.remarks:
This is useful for reading a (singular) child element of an xml element into an object that implements . This also gives you a way to create the instance used for the child object programatically.
If your child class does not require special construction logic and has a default constructor, you can use instead.

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.XmlExtensions.GetSizeAttributes(System.Xml.XmlElement,System.String)
member.summary: Gets a struct as a set of attributes of the specified
member.remarks:
This will read attributes with suffixes "-width" and "-height" prefixed by . For example, if you specify "myProperty" as the base name, then it will read attributes "myProperty-width" and "myProperty-height".
Both the width and height must be specified as attributes for this to return a value.
member.param: Element to read the width and height attributes from
member.returns: A size struct if both the width and height attributes are specified, or null otherwise

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.XmlExtensions.SetSizeAttributes(System.Xml.XmlElement,System.String,System.Nullable{Eto.Drawing.Size})
member.summary: Sets attributes on the specified with width and height attributes of the specified value
member.remarks:
This will write attributes with suffixes "-width" and "-height" prefixed by . For example, if you specify "myProperty" as the base name, then it will write attributes "myProperty-width" and "myProperty-height".
Passing null as the size will not write either attribute value.
member.param: Element to write the width and height attributes on
Value to set the width and height attributes, if not null

member.name: M:Eto.Drawing.XmlExtensions.WriteChildSizeXml(System.Xml.XmlElement,System.String,System.Nullable{Eto.Drawing.Size})
member.summary: Writes the specified size to a child of the specified with the given name
member.remarks: The child element will contain "width" and "height" attributes for the value of the size. If the value is null, no child element will be written.
member.param: Element to append the child element to if is not null
Name of the element to append
